metadata.sermon_start_end: We extend a very special welcome today to those who do not often come to church. This sermon is written with you in mind. It’s always fascinating to try to figure out what Easter means to people who aren’t usually here. As a matter of fact, it’s revealing to [...] I trust the witnesses. That’s what we all are, in the last analysis — witnesses. The Christian faith, in the last analysis, is built on trust in the witnesses. That’s what the preacher is today, and that’s all the preacher ever is — one who testifies to the truth. Alleluia!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses sharply on the specific 'strange' ending of Mark. It identifies what is unique to this text (the terror and silence) compared to other gospels. However, it occasionally drifts into a general polemic against 'greeting card' religion rather than staying strictly within the textual mechanics of Mark 16.
quotes: Among the four gospel accounts of Easter morning, Mark’s is the most unsettling.
The impression given by Mark is one of real terror and utter inability to cope with the news just received.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Deepen the focus on why *this* specific silence in verse 8 is the Word of God for today, rather than using it primarily as a foil for cultural criticism.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates awareness of the textual history (the alternative endings) and the literary intent of Mark. There is a clear understanding of the 'bald' nature of the narrative. However, there is no explicit use of Greek or deep historical-critical exegesis beyond general scholarly consensus.
quotes: Most scholars now believe that Mark intended to end this way...
Matthew and Luke have toned it down considerably.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate more rigorous exegetical depth regarding the specific Greek terms for 'trembling' (tromos) and 'bewildered' (ekstasis) to highlight the ontological shock Dekker expects.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete, specifically referencing the tragedy in Grosse Pointe and the 'Rancho Santa Fe' cult. It avoids general 'spring' platitudes. It addresses the zeitgeist of skepticism among clergy and the 'Christmas syndrome' of Easter.
quotes: the wife of a leading Detroit banker was struck by a hit-and-run driver in a supermarket parking lot and left to die.
Those poor misguided souls in Rancho Santa Fe believed in life after death.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: The application to the 'visitor' mentioned in the introduction remains somewhat abstract; connect the 'terror' of the text more directly to the specific anxieties of the unchurched listener.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat traditional structure: cultural observation, then textual exposition, then contemporary examples. While the themes overlap, the 'movement' where the hearer is 'expounded' by the text is interrupted by long sections of cultural polemic.
quotes: Now don’t get me wrong. I delight in filling my house with flowers...
Now I don’t know if you are aware of this or not, but in this century...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Reduce the anecdotal 'I' and the meta-commentary on greeting cards to allow the text's own movement to confront the listener more directly.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is well-articulated as the 'furrows of the grave' and the 'terror' of the women. Redemption is external (God's act). Gratitude is present but less developed, appearing mostly as the 'trust in witnesses' at the end.
quotes: The furrows of the grave — that is all the women could see...
Resurrection means that something utterly new and unlooked for has been done by God in the midst of a dying world.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'gratitude' aspect by showing how the 'terror' of the text specifically produces a new way of living in the world, rather than just a 'gift of faith'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: While the sermon mentions the 'world-overturning power' and the need to 'relinquish dependence,' it lacks the sharp Dekkerian 'two ways'—the possibility of being lost. It leans toward a universal victory without the gravity of the narrow way.
quotes: recognizing this utterly new truth means that we will sooner or later be led to relinquish our dependence...
the decree has been set aside. It has been set aside in Christ.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of *not* hearing the message. If the women fled in fear, what is the 'temporal loss' for the modern hearer who remains in 'generic Easter'?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon distinguishes between 'immortality' (human-centered) and 'Resurrection' (Christ-centered). The doctrine of the two natures is implied in the discussion of a 'historical person' who is also the 'Creator of nature'.
quotes: Christ has entered death and descended into hell for our sakes...
He is not here — he is risen.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make the 'extra-nos' (outside of us) character of Christ's work even more explicit to counter the 'psychological help' trap Dekker warns about.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 18-19 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is slightly below the minimum threshold for 'depth needing breadth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical middle section to reach the 20-minute mark, providing more 'breadth' to the specific Markan theology.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong theological protest against the 'naturalization' of the Gospel, aligning well with Dekker's emphasis on the sermon as a form of the Word of God. It falls short on the required length (Thesis 8) and the explicit 'two ways' (Thesis 6). It successfully identifies the 'nowhere else' quality of Mark 16:8—the holy terror—but spends significant time on cultural anecdotes that occasionally distract from the specific text.
strengths: Specific focus on the unique ending of Mark's Gospel.
Sharp distinction between nature (spring) and revelation (resurrection).
weaknesses: Duration is under the 20-minute threshold required for 'depth'.
Lack of the 'two ways' or the seriousness of being lost/judgment.
Over-reliance on the preacher's personal anecdotes ('I was in a gift shop', 'I was in Grosse Pointe').
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate sermon that approaches the Dekkerian ideal through its Christocentric focus and rejection of general truths, but it requires more exegetical 'breadth' and a sharper focus on the 'two ways' to be considered a full actualization of the Word.
